revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Tagasauris | foundation = December, 2010 <!-- this parameter modifies "Founded" --> | location_city = [[New York, New York]] | location_country = USA | industry = Crowdsourcing, Semantic Web, Media and Entertainment, Social Production | services = Media Annotation, Semantic Enrichment, Named Entity Recognition | homepage = http://tagasauris.com/ }} '''Tagasauris''' is a technology [[startup company]] that was founded in New York City in December 2010. Tagasauris provides media annotation services and uses a combination of crowdsourcing, gamification, machine intelligence, and semantics to create and discover key tags for characteristics of the media object that is being annotated.<ref>Bud Mathaisel and Galen Gruman. [http://www.pwc.com/us/en/technology-forecast/2012/issue3/index.jhtml Getting past the hype of gamification] ''PWC Technology Forecast'' (Fall 2012).</ref>
Tagasauris is providing photo tagging services to [[Magnum Photos]], in order to allow the digital archive of Magnum to be searchable. The project allowed volunteers to get early access to the (untagged) photo archive of Magnum Photos, and provides descriptive, semantic tags to the images.<ref>Estrin, James. [http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/07/26/crowd-sourcing-the-magnum-archive/ "Crowd-Sourcing the Magnum Archive"] ''[[New York Times]]'' (July 26, 2011).</ref><ref>Russeth, Andrew. [http://www.observer.com/2011/08/good-morning-creative-thinking-edition/ "Good Morning! Creative Thinking Edition"] ''[[New York Observer]]'' (August 29, 2011).</ref><ref>[http://www.lemonde.fr/culture/article/2011/08/15/magnum-appelle-a-taguer-ses-archives_1559769_3246.html "Magnum appelle à "taguer" ses archives"] ''[[Le Monde]]'' (August 15, 2011){{Fr icon}}</ref><ref>Jarvis, Alice-Azania [http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/who-what-where-magnum-is-hoping-the-modern-crowd-will-help-them-identify-a-historic-archive-2332056.html?action=Gallery&ino=6 "Who, what, where? Magnum is hoping the modern crowd will help them identify a historic archive"] ''[[The Independent]]'' (August 5, 2011)</ref><ref>Grundvig, James [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/james-grundvig/big-data-tagasauris-ceo_b_1973567.html Graphing the Spillway of Big Data: Interview With Tagasauris CEO Todd Carter] ''[[Huffington Post.]]'' (October 17, 2012)</ref>
A notable accomplishment for Tagasauris, achieved through a combination of machine and human intelligence, was the discovery of a set of "lost" photos in the Magnum archive, from the shooting of the movie [[American Graffiti]]:<ref>Benenson, Fred. [http://www.wired.com/magazine/2011/06/pl_americangraffiti/ "Hidden Treasure: Lost Photos From the Set of American Graffiti"] ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' (July 2011).</ref> While the crowdsourced workers could easily identify the individuals (e.g., [[George Lucas]], [[Ron Howard]], [[Richard Dreyfuss]], and [[Mackenzie Phillips]], shown in separate photos from one shooting), the underlying machine processes connected these together to see what is common among them. The film American Graffiti was one of the suggestions.<ref>Mims, Christopher. [http://www.technologyreview.com/blog/mimssbits/26906/ "How Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon Unearthed Lost Photos From American Graffiti"] ''[[Technology Review]]'' (June 20, 2011).</ref> Tagasauris found nearly two dozen previously lost photos taken on the film’s set. "''Computers couldn’t ID humans in the photo but humans couldn’t know the context.''"<ref>Weise, Karen. [http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/humans-plus-computers-equals-better-crowdsourcing-11102011.html "Humans Plus Computers Equals Better Crowdsourcing"] ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]'' (November 10, 2011).</ref>
